pullRequest.body:
This PR adds the `algebraize` tactic, which automatically adds `Algebra`, and if possible `IsScalarTower` instances corresponding to `RingHom`s given as arguments to the tactic.

It will also search through the local context for `RingHom` properties of those `RingHom`s, and add the corresponding `Algebra` properties. The `RingHom` properties which have a corresponding `Algebra` property should be tagged using the `algebraize` attribute, which is also given in this PR. That attribute takes a name of a the corresponding `Algebra` property as an attribute, or of a constructor for such a property (this is needed when the proof of the corresponding `Algebra` property is not just given by a term the `RingHom` property).

For examples of its usage, see the files in `RingTheory/` which are also modified in this PR.

Most of this tactic was created during the AIM workshop "Formalizing algebraic geometry" in June 2024.

Co-authored by: Johan Commelin, Nick Kuhn, Arend Mellendijk, Christian Merten, Adam Topaz
(there might have been more, please let me know if you are not in this list!)

I actually like the config idea. Here is a snippet how other tactics like `simp`, `rw`, etc. do this:

(EDITED code)

```lean
namespace Algebraize

[...]

structure Config where
  searchContext : Bool := true
deriving Inhabited

declare_config_elab elabAlgebraizeConfig Algebraize.Config

end Algebraize

open Algebraize Lean.Parser.Tactic

/-- Tactic that, given `RingHom`s, adds the corresponding `Algebra` and (if possible)
`IsScalarTower` instances, as well as `Algebra` corresponding to `RingHom` properties available
as hypotheses.

Example: given `f : A +* B` and `g : B +* C`, and `hf : f.FiniteType`, `algebraize f g` will add
the instances `Algebra A B`, `Algebra B C`, and `Algebra.FiniteType A B`.

See the `algebraize` tag for instructions on what properties can be added. -/
syntax "algebraize" (config)? (ppSpace colGt term:max)* : tactic

elab_rules : tactic
  | `(tactic| algebraize $[$config]? $[$t:term]*) => do
    let cfg  elabAlgebraizeConfig (mkOptionalNode config)
    let t  t.mapM fun i => Term.elabTerm i none
    -- We loop through the given terms and add algebra instances
    for f in t do
      let ft  inferType f
      match ft.getAppFn with
      | Expr.const ``RingHom _ => addAlgebraInstanceFromRingHom f ft
      | _ => throwError m!"{f} is not of type `RingHom`"
    -- After having added the algebra instances we try to add scalar tower instances
    for f in t do
      match f.getAppFn with
      | Expr.const ``RingHom.comp _ =>
        try addIsScalarTowerInstanceFromRingHomComp f
        catch _ => continue
      | _ => continue

    -- Search through the local context to find other instances of algebraize
    if cfg.searchContext then
      searchContext t

```

My suggestion is to use the suggestion `algebraize_only`. That sounds reasonable.

With `algebraize only` I would argue that `algebraize only [f, g, f.comp g]` somehow looks unexpected. For me the `only`-keyword would suggest that whatever follows is a subset of all tagged declarations, i.e. I'd rather expect `algebraize only [RingHom.Finite]` to work, which might not integrate well: `algebraize only [RingHom.Finite] at f g (f.comp g)` would be uniform with other tactics, but then we're back at the sequence of terms... (on a techincal level, it wouldn't be difficult: one could directly [copy the syntax from `simp`](https://github.com/leanprover/lean4/blob/e9e858a4484905a0bfe97c4f05c3924ead02eed8/src/Init/Tactics.lean#L570-L571))

That would be very cool to implement! @kim-em what do you think about this `algebraize only [...] at ...` syntax as in Jon's new suggestion? Or maybe I just call the macro `algebraize_only` for now, so that some version of this reaches mathlib, and then work on `algebraize only` after.

I think the problem is that usually the `at ...` is essentially a sequence of `ident`s, but here it would be an undeterminated sequence of `term`s, which is much more general and the reason Kim was worried about parsing errors (if I understand correctly). So this would require thinking again about the way `f.comp g` is handled. This might be out-of-scope for this PR.

For the sake of preserving your own efforts, I would say just use `algebraize_only` here and work this out in a follow-up PR if you have the motivation. We already kept adding more and more, and I think it would be better to get a first version merged and then have improvements in follow-up PRs.
switched to `algebraize_only` and config options`properties`. for now

```suggestion
/-- Function that extracts the name of the corresponding `Algebra` property from a `RingHom`
```
B doesn't have to be commutative, no?

I believe the tactic mainly uses [RingHom.toAlgebra](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Algebra/Algebra/Defs.html#RingHom.toAlgebra):

```lean
def RingHom.toAlgebra {A B} [CommSemiring A] [CommSemiring B] (i : A +* B) : Algebra A B
```

which assumes that both `A` and `B` are commutative.
Why do we need to write `g.comp f` separately? Surely the tactic could identify composable pairs of specified RingHoms automatically?

This would be nice to implement, but @callesonne I think it is also fine if you add this as

```
## Future work

* If source/target match, automatically add `(g.comp f)` when calling `algebraize f g`
```

to the module docstring if you don't feel like looking at how to implement it now.

@semorrison we discussed this during the workshop, but an issue that comes up is that say you have three morphisms `f : A -> B` and `g, h : B -> C`. Then, if adding the algebra instance corresponding to the compositions is automatic, you would add two algebra instances `Algebra A C` which becomes a problem. So that's why we decided to force the user to supply the compositions themselves.

```suggestion
`f : A +* B` and `g : B +* C` are `RingHom`s, will add the instances `Algebra A B` and
```

```suggestion
/-- Version of `algebraize`, which only adds `Algebra` instances and `IsScalarTower` instances,
but not ...... -/
```
@callesonne Please expand this docstring to explain what `algebraize'` does *not* do compared to `algebraize`.
Yes will do, sorry I was away (and needed to prepare a talk) for a conference!
done

```suggestion
When given a composition of `RingHom`s, e.g. `algebraize (g.comp f)`, the tactic will also try to
add the instance `IsScalarTower A B C` if possible.
```

```suggestion
@[algebraize Module.Finite]
def RingHom.Finite (f : A +* B) : Prop :=
  letI : Algebra A B := f.toAlgebra
  Module.Finite A B
```

I have a hunch that some of the regression could come from the fact that we are using `MVarId.note` (`have` decl) instead of `MVarId.define` (`let` decl) here... Does anybody know how to construct the expected type of `val`? (added template as comment)

I moved my debugging commits to

- leanprover-community/mathlib4#17284
Very odd that it has regressed, given that an earlier bench showed no significant changes.
Somehow I think the regression boils down to the import change (which shake suggested). Undoing that everything is fine again.

I realised now that this change I made wouldn't be necessary: since all ring properties are always `Prop` (at least so far), I think it doesn't matter if one uses `mvarid.define` or `mvarid.note` in `addProperties` due to proof-irrelevance.

So this construction of the expected type above here could be removed again
I don't think this is a critical issue. So let's fix it in a follow-up PR. Because this tactic is going to be very helpful in the immediate future.

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat(Tactic/Algebraize): add algebraize tactic
